titleInfo.title: Letter and yarn sample from Mary Crovatt Hambidge to Margaret Croft

mods.abstract: One-page letter to Margaret, with an accompanying sample of dyed gold yarn. Mary writes of making a "very handsome" cord using this yarn. She gives Margaret instructions on how to order more yarn, and labels it "Coarse Cotton No. 3, Colour 79."

Mary Crovatt (1885-1973), a former model and singer from Georgia, ventured to Greece with artist Jay Hambidge (1867-1924) in 1919, and it was there that she started working with textiles and weaving. She later took Jay's last name, even though the two never married. In 1934, Mary started the Hambidge Center in Rabun Gap, GA, a retreat and sustainable farm based on her ideas about Jay's concept of "dynamic symmetry," and the relationship between nature and creativity. From the beginning, Mary worked with local women on weaving projects to display in exhibits around the country, and opened a shop in New York City for their wares. The Hambidge Center still exists today as a retreat and community for artists and craftspeople. Margaret Croft was a frequent visitor to the Hambidge Center, learning to weave there and cultivating a friendship with Hambidge herself.
